Program Description  The  program  loan  will  support  implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction  Program  outlined  under  the  development  partner-
funded Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC 6), as part 
of the Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010 of 
the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  (the  Government).  The  SEDP 
provides a medium-term framework for this 5-year cycle of PRSC 
operations that comprises poverty reduction policies, programs, 
and actions with specific targets for development outcomes by 
2010.  
   
Rationale  The  official  development  assistance  (ODA)  community  in  Viet 
Nam  considers  the  PRSC  to  be  an  important  instrument  for 
supporting  SEDP  implementation.  As  a  multisector  instrument 
covering a range of issues related to poverty reduction, the PRSC 
framework provides the Asian Development Bank (ADB) with an 
opportunity to (i) advance and widen the national policy dialogue 
in  a  well-coordinated  and  comprehensive  manner,  (ii)  provide 
lending and nonlending assistance in coordination with other ODA 
partners, and (iii) ensure that key policy issues affecting ADB 
operations  in  Viet  Nam  are  addressed  in  the  policy  dialogue 
between  the  Government  and  the  ODA  community  to  help 
achieve the common goal of poverty reduction and growth.  
   
  In addition to ADB, the World Bank and other major ODA partners 
intend to contribute both financial and intellectual resources to 
PRSC 6. ODA partners include Australia, Canada, Denmark, the 
European  Commission,  Germany,  Ireland,  Japan,  the 
Netherlands, Spain, and the United Kingdom. Switzerland, while 
not a financing partner, provided financial support for coordinating 
the process. The International Monetary Fund, France, and the 
United  Nations  Development  Programme  participated  in  the 
PRSC policy dialogue.

ii 
  The current cycle of PRSCs is a vehicle for the donor community 
to stay engaged with Viet Nam, and has delivered outstanding 
performance in terms of economic growth and poverty reduction in 
the previous cycle. The PRSC is the only instrument that allows 
donors to actively engage in supporting a comprehensive, cross-
cutting  reform  agenda  in  Viet  Nam.  The  coherence  of  the 
comprehensive reform program under the PRSCs, particularly the 
fundamental governance reforms, helps ensure the effectiveness 
of sectoral interventions by ADB and other donors. Both economic 
growth and changes in the social environment have occurred at a 
rapid pace in recent years, and active and frequent engagement 
through PRSCs should help improve the content of specific policy 
actions, ensure their timely adoption, and assist in monitoring the 
impact of the overall program on broader development outcomes.   
   
  ADB has been actively involved in formulating PRSC 6, and has 
promoted policy dialogue on similar issues through its program 
lending activities and sector policy reforms. PRSC 6 complements 
ADB’s support of Viet Nam’s policy and institutional reforms.  
   
  The  proposed  loan  adheres  to  ADB’s  recent  efforts  to  adopt 
program-based and sector approaches in its lending operations, 
so as to reduce transaction costs, both for developing member 
countries and its own operations. The approach is consistent with 
ADB’s  reform  agenda,  long-term  strategic  framework,  and 
medium-term strategies I and II, and will directly help fulfill ADB’s 
obligations to the Rome Declaration on harmonizing procedures of 
multilateral development banks (2003) and the Paris Declaration 
on Aid Effectiveness (2005). 
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected impact of the proposed loan is to reduce poverty 
and sustain high economic growth in Viet Nam. The proposed 
loan  will  help  fund  PRSC  6  and  thereby  (i)  reduce  structural 
weaknesses and improve the business environment, (ii) promote 
social inclusion, (iii) protect natural resources, and (iv) modernize 
governance. 
   
Cost Estimates  Some  of  the  reforms  supported  by  the  PRSC  process  entail 
substantial costs to be financed by the state. Policy measures 
supported by the PRSC operations require additional spending.  
   
  The estimated cost of some specific PRSC-related measures for 
the  PRSC  6  implementation  period  is  approximately  $1,420 
million, i.e., (i) health care funds for the poor—about $90 million, 
(ii)  increased  spending  on  education  proportional  to  the 
Government  budget—about  $540  million,  (iii)  social  safety  net 
program  for  the  retrenched  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE) 
workers—about  $100  million,  and  (iv)  state-owned  commercial 
bank (SOCB) recapitalization—about $690 million.

iii 
Financing Plan  A total of about $354 million for PRSC 6 operations is expected to 
be funded through ODA resources. The World Bank has already 
approved a $175 million credit from the International Development 
Association  to  support  PRSC  6.  Financing  partners  providing 
parallel concessional loans include ADB ($15 million), the Japan 
Bank for International Cooperation (¥3.5 billion), and Germany (€6 
million).  Financing  partners  providing  grants  include  Agencia 
Española de Cooperación Internacional (€5 million), Australian 
Agency for International Development (A$10 million), Canadian 
International  Development  Agency  (Can$7.5  million),  Danish 
International  Development  Agency  (DKr61  million),  European 
Commission  (€20  million),  Ireland  (€7.5  million),  Netherlands 
Ministry of Development Cooperation (€12 million), and United 
Kingdom’s  Department  for  International  Development  (₤20 
million). Swiss Development Cooperation, while not a financing 
partner of PRSC 6, provided financial support for coordination of 
the process. 
   
Loan Amount and Terms  A loan equivalent to $15 million in special drawing rights from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources will be provided. The loan will 
have  a  24-year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  an 
interest rate of 1.0% during the grace period and 1.5% during the 
amortization period, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in the draft loan agreement. The loan proceeds may be used to 
finance eligible imports incurred within 180 days prior to the date 
of  loan  effectiveness.  The  loan  reflects  ADB’s  support  for 
implementation of the SEDP following the policy framework of the 
PRSC 6 program. The loan will contribute to financing adjustment 
costs resulting from implementation of the policy matrix and will 
support and facilitate the Government’s continued and deepened 
reform program for poverty reduction. 
   
Disbursement  The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon declaration of 
loan effectiveness. 
   
Period of Utilization  The loan will be fully utilized by 31 December 2008. 
   
Executing Agency  The State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV) will be the Executing Agency. 
SBV works in close collaboration with the World Bank to prepare 
and implement the PRSCs.

iv 
Implementation  The Steering Committee was established in June 2007 to advise 
Arrangements  the  Prime  Minister  in  developing  and  implementing  the 
Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  and 
Poverty  Reduction  Support  Credits  in  consistence  with  the 
purposes of the Scioeconomic Development Plan  2006–2010., 
Such committee is chaired by the deputy prime minister in charge 
of  economic  reforms,  and  consists  of  representatives  from 
relevant line ministries and government agencies. An SBV deputy 
governor  and  a  vice  minister  of  the  Ministry  of  Planning  and 
Investment act as the standing vice chairpersons. To represent 
PRSC policy reform areas, the steering committee has several 
representatives from key economic ministries (e.g., the ministries 
of  agriculture  and  rural  development;  education  and  training; 
finance;  foreign  affairs;  justice;  industry  and  trade;  and  labor, 
invalids,  and social  affairs;  and),  as well  as  the  Office  of  the 
Government. 
   
Procurement  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign 
exchange  costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items 
produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding 
ineligible  items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral sources. In accordance with the provisions of ADB’s 
Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans, the proceeds of the program 
loan will be disbursed to Viet Nam as the Borrower.  
   
  No supporting import documentation will be required, provided the 
value of Viet Nam’s total imports minus imports from nonmember 
countries,  ineligible  imports,  and  imports  financed  under  other 
official development assistance is equal to or greater than the 
amount of the loan expected to be disbursed. The Government 
will  certify  its  compliance  with  this  formula  with  its  withdrawal 
request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing 
procedures will be required. ADB will have the right to audit the 
use of loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the Borrower's 
certification.  As  such,  the  procedures  for  procurement  and 
disbursement of funds, and the use of counterpart funds, are felt 
to be satisfactory.

v 
Project Benefits and  The proposed loan will benefit the Vietnamese people in four 
Beneficiaries  ways. First, through policy actions designed to facilitate business 
development,  the  loan  will  increase  efficiency,  accelerate 
economic growth, and create jobs. These policy actions will help 
improve the regulatory framework for private sector development, 
and enhance transparency and accountability in SOE operations 
and in banking. Second, policy actions addressing social inclusion 
will result in benefits that include improved quality of education, 
improved access of the poor to health services, a reformed social 
protection  system,  and  promotion  of  gender  equality.  Third, 
through policy actions addressing natural resources, the loan will 
help secure land ownership and address the resettlement and 
compensation process, as well as promoting more sustainable 
management of natural resources. Fourth, through policy actions 
addressing  modern  governance,  benefits  include  increased 
transparency and accountability of public finances, and improved 
legal  transparency  and  accessibility.  These  will  be  achieved 
through better coordination of plans and budgets, adoption of the 
medium-term expenditure framework, and greater accountability 
in public finance and public administration.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  There are three potential risks associated with imbalances that 
may emerge as Viet Nam achieves greater global integration and 
market-orientation.  
   
  The first potential risk is the vulnerability that stems from possible 
turbulence in the financial sector. The supervisory and regulatory 
capacity  of  monetary  authorities  has  not  kept  pace  with  the 
expansion  of  capital  markets.  The  second  risk  relates  to  the 
massive  inflows  of  foreign  direct  investment  and  increased 
competition in formerly protected sectors. This change may test 
the ability of Viet Nam to preserve social inclusion, and may cause 
some groups to lose in the short term. The third possible risk 
involves  potential  corruption  and  social  strife  related  to  rapid 
urbanization and infrastructure development.  
   
  The Government is aware of the potential risks, and will mitigate 
these by considering and implementing appropriate measures and 
proactive programs during program implementation.  
   
  ADB, along with other PRSC financing partners, has conducted 
analytical  studies  to  help  policymakers  formulate  and  execute 
mitigating  and  corrective  measures  in  anticipation  of  these 
potential  risks.  These  corrective  measures  have  been 
incorporated in the series of PRSCs, which include this program 
loan.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Support  the  Implementation  of  the  Poverty 
Reduction Program IV (SIPRP IV). The program loan follows a program-based approach and is 
part of the Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC 6), jointly processed by several 
development  partners,  in  support  of  implementation  by  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  (the 
Government) of the Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010. The design and 
monitoring framework for the program loan is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
2.  Over the last 20 years, Viet Nam’s economy has been transformed significantly. It has 
become  one  of  the  fastest-growing  economies  in  Asia,  recording  average  annual  gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth of 7.5% over the last decade. GDP per capita increased from 
$288 in 1993 to $716 in 2006, with marginal increase in inequality. At the same time, the 
poverty incidence in the country declined sharply, from about 58.0% in 1993, to 28.9% in 2002, 
and 19.5% in 2004 (see Table A2.1 in Appendix 2).  
 
3.  Economic growth in Viet Nam has been largely equitable. Expenditure inequality (as 
measured by Gini coefficient) has increased only marginally during the 1990s. Nonetheless, 
some groups have benefited less and are vulnerable to social and economic marginalization. 
These include people living with low levels of human capital, ethnic minorities, and to some 
extent, women. Social indicators (such as school enrollment and health care) are lower for 
these groups. Low-income households face a vicious cycle of remaining poor due to difficulties 
in accessing health and education services, especially if user fees are involved.1 There are also 
considerable  disparities  in  poverty  and  poverty  reduction  across  regions.  The  northern 
mountains, the north central coast, and the central highlands all have high poverty incidence 
rates (over 30%), which are substantially higher than in other regions. These regions are home 
to nearly 57% of the total poor population.2  
 
4.  The impressive outcomes of simultaneous continuing high economic growth and rapid 
poverty reduction were achieved through a combination of sustained business-led growth in 
economic output and employment and government-led targeted poverty reduction interventions. 
The  latter  include,  for  example,  programs  focusing  on  (i)  hunger  eradication  and  poverty 
reduction (Program 143); (ii) socioeconomic development in communes with extreme difficulties 
(Program 135); (iii) heath care for the poor (Program 139); (iv) compensation for job losses due 
to state enterprise reform (Social Safety Net Fund); (v) schooling at all levels, including adult-
and-non-formal, and life-long learning (Education for All); and (vi) helping  ethnic minorities 
catch up with the overall socioeconomic development (Advancing Ethnic Minorities). Viet Nam’s 
transition from central planning to a socialist-oriented market economic system has involved the 
liberalization of markets, recognition of private property rights, and a gradual opening up of the 
economy to external markets for trade and investment. The growth of the private sector has 
been a significant feature of economic development. The structure of the economy is changing 
markedly, with a steady increase in the industrial and service sectors. Greater diversification in 
industrial production and services is laying the foundations for sustained growth in output and 
employment.

A.  Development Objectives, Strategies, and Plans 
5.  The Government of Viet Nam is committed to poverty reduction and considers it to be an 
overarching objective in its national socioeconomic development process. Evidence  of  the 
Government’s commitment includes a series of strategic plans and documents, including the 10-
Year Socioeconomic Development Strategy 2001–2010, the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction 
and  Growth  Strategy  (CPRGS)  2002–2006,  the  5-Year  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan 
(SEDP) 2001–2005, and SEDP 2006–2010. The SEDP 2006–2010 is considered Viet Nam’s 
national strategy for poverty reduction and growth, which articulates the vision for Viet Nam to 
attain middle-income status by 2010. The SEDP is recognized as a blueprint for development, 
because  it  is  based  on  empirical  analysis  and  broad  consultation,  and  identifies  clear 
development outcomes, specifies policies to attain its goals, and aligns public resources to 
implement these policies.  
 
6.  Viet Nam’s development strategy is embodied in the SEDP 2006–2010, which was 
endorsed by the National Assembly in June 2006. The SEDP is expected to be Viet Nam’s new 
national strategy for poverty reduction and growth. Reducing poverty incidence to 10–11% by 
2010 is an overarching goal of the SEDP 2006–2010. Its aims include, among others, to (i) 
accelerate and sustain economic growth and development; (ii) significantly improve people’s 
material, cultural, and spiritual life; (iii) create the foundations to boost industrialization and 
modernization and to gradually develop a knowledge-based economy; and (iv) enhance Viet 
Nam’s status in the region and the world. The SEDP has a strong results-orientation, with 
performance  indicators  that  include  the  Viet  Nam  Development  Goals  (VDGs)  and  the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The SEDP was prepared in an intensively participatory 
and consultative manner with substantive inputs from a broad range of interest groups. The 
main targets are specified to ensure sustainable development across the economy, society, and 
environment.  
 
7.  In the SEDP, the Government embraces reform actions that fall broadly into four main 
areas: (i) the promotion of growth and transition to a market economy; (ii) reducing poverty and 
ensuring social inclusion; (iii) managing the environment and natural resources in a sustainable 
manner; and (iv) building institutions that can support the strategy. The first three pillars are 
explicitly listed in the SEDP, while the fourth is introduced in the monitoring and evaluation 
(M&E) framework. The fourth pillar is recognized as the foundation for making progress on the 
first three. Intended reform actions under the four pillars will be carried out with the goal of 
achieving middle-income status by end-2010. The Asian Development Bank (ADB), World Bank 
and  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  have  helped  develop  the  results-
framework and M&E framework of the Government’s SEDP in close collaboration with other 
development partners. Appendix 2 presents details on the SEDP in the context of PRSC 
operations.  
 
8.  The Government and development partners realize that the impressive gains in poverty 
reduction realized to date remain fragile. In addition, achieving further poverty reductions will 
become increasingly difficult, as gains will be harder to  realize among more marginalized 
groups. Providing services to rural poor and ethnic minorities who live in remote areas requires 
more marginal resources. To help the poor in mountainous areas increase land use productivity, 
especially productivity of forest land, the Government revised the Law on Forest Protection and 
Development in 2004 and issued the related Forest Development Strategy (2006–2010) in 
February  2007,  providing  guidance  on  moving  toward  more  social  and  community-based 
forestry. The strategy recognizes the forest-use rights of households and communities and their

3 
ownership of plantation forests. The issuance of such strategies is one of the policy actions 
proposed in this program loan.  
  
9.  An additional factor complicating future poverty reduction is the large number of the 
near-poor. A significant proportion of the population was just below the poverty line in 1993, and 
had barely moved above the poverty line by 1998; they remain vulnerable to shocks that could 
push them  back below the poverty  line. Future challenges include  (i) allocating additional 
resources, (ii) the ability to mobilize external resources, (iii) improved targeting of resources, (iv) 
enhanced  efficiency  by  making  social  services  more  demand  driven,  and  (v)  improved 
monitoring systems that ensure benefits actually reach the poor. 
 
10.  Viet Nam became a World Trade Organization (WTO) member in January 2007, and 
further  integration of  Viet Nam’s  economy  into  the  global and  regional economy will help 
stimulate structural reforms and open access to markets, capital and technology, resulting in 
higher economic productivity. Globalization and regional integration bring opportunities but also 
challenges, including for groups employed by enterprises that are no longer competitive, and 
which consequently lose their jobs. The SEDP 2006–2010 has shifted the focus of priority areas 
from  basic  structural  reforms  to  more  complex  issues—including  building  inclusive  and 
financially viable social insurance systems—so as to respond to the needs of those negatively 
impacted by global integration in the short term. The National Assembly passed the Social 
Insurance Law in November 2006, which is one of the policy actions under this program loan. 
Other priorities of the SEDP 2006–2010, which are also priorities of the PRSC operations, 
include (i) strengthening the supervision of financial markets, (ii) regulating access to and 
pricing of infrastructure services, (iii) managing natural resources and protecting environment, 
and (iv) increasing transparency and accountability at all levels.  
 
B.  Recent Economic Performance 
 
11.  Viet Nam is one of the fastest-growing economies in Asia, recording an average annual 
growth in GDP of about 7.5% over the last decade. Underpinned by rapid growth in private 
investment, strong consumption and robust exports, GDP growth accelerated to 8% for 2006 
and an estimated 8.3% for 2007,3 above its trend rate of the last 10 years. Demand for the 
country’s  exports  of  commodities,  crude  oil,  and  manufactures  was  strong,  and  private 
investment  and  private  consumption  also  recorded  robust  growth.  Growth  in  private 
consumption was supported by rising incomes and inward remittances of about $4 billion in 
2006.  Increasing consumption is partly a result of favorable demographics, as Viet Nam has 
one of youngest populations in Asia, with more than 65% of the population below 30 years of 
age. Retail sales of goods and services increased by 20.9% in 2006 (about 13% after adjusting 
for inflation), higher than the 16.9% average recorded over the previous 5 years.  
 
12.  Exports  performed  strongly  in  2006,  rising  by  23.0%  in  nominal  US  dollar  terms, 
compared with average annual growth of 17% from 2001–2005. The ratio of exports to GDP 
increased from about 55% in 2000 to 66% in 2006, indicating the openness of the economy 
even before Viet Nam joined the WTO in January 2007. The structure of exports is becoming 
more diversified; while unprocessed commodities such as crude oil, rice, marine products, and 
agriculture products remain important, the share of manufactured products is rising. Robust 
domestic demand, particularly from investment projects, caused imports to grow by 33.3%. As a 
consequence, the trade deficit was estimated at $4.5 billion, equivalent to 8.7% of GDP in 2006. 
Vigorous expansion in both private remittances and tourism receipts helped limit the current

account deficit to $1.26 billion, or 2.1% of GDP in 2006. Buoyant foreign direct investment (FDI) 
inflows supported the balance of payments, resulting in a rise in gross international reserves to

13.  From the production side, the industry and services sectors contributed more than 90% 
of total GDP growth in 2006. Industry expanded by a robust 10.4%, slightly below the pace in 
2005. The services sector, supported by buoyant performance in trade, tourism, transportation, 
telecommunications,  and  financial  services,  grew  by  an  estimated  8.2%,  higher  than  the 
average of 2001–2005. Inflation remained high, exceeding 7% on average during 2006 for the 
third year in a row. The high inflation rate was mainly a result of a jump in food prices caused by 
strong demand. However, the inflation rate is projected to decrease in 2007 and 2008 due to 
reduced tariff rates following WTO accession, and expected reductions in crude oil prices in the 
world market.  
 
14.  The overall fiscal deficit remained high in 2006 at 5.0% of GDP, slightly above the 4.8% 
average of the last five years so as to finance the required infrastructure investment. Fiscal 
revenues surpassed the planned target by 10%. Total revenue (excluding grants) stands at 24% 
of GDP. This increase was attributable to higher oil revenues (accounting for about 29% of total 
revenue),  improvements  in  tax  administration,  and  the  growing  number  of  tax-paying 
businesses in the formal sector. Off-budget expenditures rose from 1.2% of GDP in 2004 to an 
estimated 2% of GDP in 2006. These are mainly used for investment in infrastructure and 
education. Investment in infrastructure now exceeds 9% of GDP and is expected to reach 11% 
in coming years. Off-budget expenditures are subject to the same scrutiny by the National 
Assembly as is budgetary spending.  
 
15.   Viet Nam is a moderately-indebted country. At the end of 2006, public and publicly-
guaranteed  debt  was  an  estimated  45.5%  of  GDP  in  nominal  terms.  External  debt  was

III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
1.  Progress in Reducing Poverty 
17.  In aggregate terms Viet Nam’s rapid progress in reducing poverty is unprecedented. No 
other country has reduced poverty incidence so much in such a short time.4 Data from the four 
Viet Nam Household Living Standards Surveys (VHLSSs) conducted in 1993, 1998, 2002, and 
2004 reveal that Viet Nam has achieved remarkable success in poverty reduction during the 
period of 1993–2004; the poverty rate, as measured by per capita consumption, has dropped 
almost 39 percentage points over this 11-year period. The poverty rate in 2004 was one-third 
the 1993 rate, meaning Viet Nam outperformed the United Nations’ Millennium Development 
Goal of halving extreme poverty over a 25-year period (1990 to 2015). The pace at which 
poverty rates have fallen has accelerated remarkably over the last few years. The poverty gap5 
indicates that those who are still in poverty are becoming less poor. In 1993, consumption of the 
average poor person was equal to 68% of the poverty line; by 2004, it had climbed to 76%. The 
remarkable performance in terms of income and expenditure is also supported by outstanding 
social indicators: improvements in the net enrollment rate, health insurance coverage, access to 
electricity, clean water, sanitation, and possession of numerous durable goods reflect significant 
improvements in people’s wellbeing. During this period relative inequality, as measured by the 
Gini index for per capita expenditures, has shown a modest increase, from 0.33 in 1993 to 0.37 
in 2004. This is comparable to other countries at a similar level of development.  
 
18.  When poverty and inequality are examined at disaggregate levels, however, significant 
variation in progress in poverty reduction can be seen across different segments of society. 
Although declines in poverty have been achieved in all major segments of society, the rate of 
decline has been slower in (i) rural areas than in urban areas, (ii) among most ethnic minority 
groups in comparison to the majority group, and (iii) in some regions than in others. Poverty has 
become largely a rural phenomenon. Three out of eight regions6 of the country have suffered

19.  An understanding of the factors responsible for past achievements in poverty reduction 
would  provide  guidance  for  future  policy  interventions.  There  is  consensus  that  poverty 
reduction has been underpinned by rapid, stable and inclusive economic growth.7 A series of 
far-reaching  market  reforms  undertaken  in  the  1990s  and  early  2000s  has  resulted  in 
improvements in the geographic and occupational mobility of labor, enabling people to take 
advantage of better income-generating opportunities. The relatively pro-poor pattern of public 
investments and budget transfers, including national poverty-targeting programs (i.e., Program 
135 and Program 143) has led to improved access by the poor to education, health care, and 
infrastructure.  Another  important  element  of  the  rapid  poverty  reduction  has  been  the 
redistribution of agricultural land to rural households. The allocation of land-use right certificates 
(LUCs) to lowland rural households amounted to a massive and egalitarian transfer of wealth. 
This resulted in a dramatic increase in agricultural production and exports, and effectively 
helped millions of households escape poverty. The three preceding loans (SIPRP I, II and III 
under the PRSC 3–5 framework) have included these critical policy reforms. Political stability 
and  broad-based  growth  in  economic  output  and  employment  also  underpinned  poverty 
reduction. 
  
20.  There are also reasons to believe that Viet Nam’s future experience with poverty may 
differ somewhat from what has occurred in the past. The current distribution of incomes and 
expenditures implies that a higher growth rate is required to achieve a one-percentage-point 
drop in poverty. This calls for further strengthening of the existing national targeting programs 
on  poverty  reduction.  In  addition,  the  relatively  large  number  of  non-poor  people  whose 
consumption is just above the poverty line level implies that protecting vulnerable people from 
falling back into poverty is becoming increasingly important for the reduction of overall poverty. 
Particularly, vulnerable groups are now facing various shocks—including communicable disease 
outbreaks, natural disasters, and sharp dips in global agricultural commodity prices—and may 
face these again in the future. The persistently high poverty incidence and depth among ethnic 
minority groups and some lagging regions is a big challenge for Viet Nam in the next five years. 
In addition, new forms of poverty will emerge, caused in part by the process of urbanization. 
 
21.   In light of these challenges, sustaining rapid poverty reduction over the next five years 
will require a combination of policy measures, including an acceleration of market-oriented 
reforms, and in particular an emphasis on development of the private sector to achieve higher 
efficiency. This would permit more rapid growth within resource constraints, as growth continues 
to be a main driver of poverty reduction. Innovative measures should also be used to enhance

  2.   The Socioeconomic Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010  
 
23.  The SEDP was finalized and approved by the National Assembly in June 2006. The 
SEDP was prepared with support of the development assistance community, including ADB, 
and in consultation with stakeholders and civil society (Appendix 2). Implementation of the 
SEDP  policy  reform  agenda  has  been  undertaken  largely  through  the  Government’s  own 
resources, supplemented by pooling of ODA grant and lending resources under the PRSC 6–10 
framework. The PRSC framework was prepared by development partners in close consultation 
with government agencies. SEDP 2006–2010 includes open discussions about disadvantaged 
groups and regions and about the challenges presented by the emergence of a growing gap 
between  socioeconomic  groups.  Issues  of  social  inclusion  are  no  longer  restricted  to  the

24.  The  Government  has  well-established  coordinating,  monitoring,  and  oversight

Committee was established in June 2007 to advise the Prime Minister on the developing and 
implementing  of  the  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  and  Poverty 
Reduction Support Credits in accordance to the purposes of the SEDP 2006–2010. Such 
steering committee is chaired by a deputy prime minister, with an SBV deputy governor and a 
vice minister of the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) as standing vice chairpersons. Its

Government  undertakes  detailed  reviews  of  implementation  progress  of  the  PRSC  reform 
agenda, and discusses findings and emerging issues with its development assistance partners, 
usually at annual consultative group meetings.

  3.  Lessons  
 
a.  Lending Modality 
30.  According to the 2001 special evaluation report on program lending by the Operations 
Evaluation Department (OED), the program’s lending modality is a welcome alternative to 
typical  program  loans,  which  are  generally  limited  to  two-tranche  programs.  The  report 
recommended that multiple and floating tranches could effectively provide flexibility in meeting 
and preserving incentives for policy changes, in remaining engaged, and in adopting a long-
term outlook.12 The innovative lending modality for the PRSCs is also referred to in the recent 
OED study Good Practices for the Evaluation of Policy-Based Lending by Multilateral Banks.13  
 
31.  While this program loan is processed as a single-tranche program loan, it is actually part 
of a multiple-tranche program loan series (PRSCs 6–10) supporting implementation of the 
SEDP  2006–2010.  The  lending  modality  for  the  PRSCs  is  (i)  based  in  part  on  past 
achievements, in that all policy actions have been achieved before loan approval, with loan 
proceeds to be disbursed immediately upon loan effectiveness, to finance adjustment costs 
arising  from  agreed  reforms;  and  (ii)  forward-looking,  in  that  each  annual  PRSC  contains 
agreements on policy triggers considered a critical bridge between the current and next PRSC. 
Policy triggers are policy reforming trends that are expected to evolve substantively during the 
subsequent PRSC. Policy triggers are not intended to be stated in the manner of conventional 
policy conditions, thus allowing for refinement of exact progress, according to the Government’s 
readiness to embark on such reform. (Appendix 2 indicates the policy areas considered critical 
for the next PRSC operation by PRSC stakeholders.) 
 
32.  The PRSCs complement rather than replace other initiatives of ADB, the World Bank, 
and other development partners. They complement other analytical studies, policy dialogues, 
and  programs  and  projects,  and  vice  versa.  Following  ADB’s  participation  as  one  of  the 
financing partners to PRSCs 3, 4 and 5 in the first 5-year PRSC cycle, ADB has confirmed its 
plan to participate in the current cycle. The program loans to support PRSCs 6–10 are included 
in the country strategy and program for 2007–2010. The coexistence of ADB sector-specific 
program loans and the PRSCs is seen as leveraging ADB’s development efforts in Viet Nam 
with  other  stakeholders.  PRSC  operations  also  provide  a  complementary  forum  to  aid 
harmonization in the country’s development agenda.

33.  The main contribution of PRSCs has been their ability to serve as a platform for a 
continued  policy  dialogue  with  key  government  counterparts  on  a  broad  range  of  issues. 
However, given the encompassing nature of Viet Nam’s reform program generally, and of the 
CPRGS agenda in particular, progress was not even across all policy areas.  Identifying strong 
and weak areas in policy making is essential to ensure the sustainability of this effort over time. 
Starting with PRSC 3, a set of indicators covering a broad range of policy areas was used to 
assess progress, but these indicators may need revision. Both the previous 5-year plan and the 
CPRGS lacked a monitoring and evaluation framework, with indicators instead derived from the 
text of those documents and from other relevant sectoral strategies and policy statements. 
 
34.  Overall, progress was slower in those policy areas characterized by limited political will, 
conflicting institutional responsibilities or insufficient analysis. The speed at which progress was 
made across policy areas within each pillar depended on the political will to implement the 
reforms.  The  contrast  between  the  rapid  progress  achieved  in  integrating  with  the  world 
economy and the slow pace of reform in the banking sector is revealing in this respect. To some 
extent, this contrast may reflect a deliberate choice, in which rapid movement towards WTO 
accession would make inevitable the need for subsequent banking sector reforms. In other 
cases (e.g., water) limited progress reflects institutional overlap and unclear delineation of 
responsibility across several ministries or agencies. In the case of corruption, there is an 
undeniable commitment to battle corruption, but it is recent, and in such instances progress 
made on inputs (such as laws, or coordinating bodies) may take considerable time to translate 
into progress on outputs and outcomes. Specifics aside, when policy areas are classified on the 
basis  of  progress  the  results  are  consistent  with  the  ratings  prepared  for  the  country 
performance assessment (CPA). Those ratings are above the regional average in relation to 
macroeconomic management and social inclusion, and below the average in relation to the 
financial sector, labor and social protection, and transparency and anticorruption.

medium term requires strong analytical work. The VDR 2007, co-signed by 16 donors, provides 
the main analytical underpinnings for the current 5-year PRSC cycle. The preparation of this 
report,  entitled  Aiming  High,  started  shortly  after  approval  of  the  SEDP  by  the  National 
Assembly. The report was submitted to the consultative group meeting of December, 2006 as a 
contribution by the international community to implementation of the SEDP. The report built on 
the analytical work done over the previous PRSC cycle on structural reforms (as summarized in 
the VDR 2006, Business), institutional modernization (VDR 2005, Governance) and on social 
inclusion (VDR 2004, Poverty). ADB has actively participated in formulating VDR 2007 by 
contributing extensive written inputs and comments. Lessons from previous PRSCs and similar 
programs  suggest  that  conducting  joint  analytical  work  between  development  partners  is 
important, along with wide consultation with academia, civil society, and the Government. The 
development partners and academia can assist the Government in terms of analytical tools and 
sharing  of  international  experience.  The  multiple-tranche  program  loan  approach  could  be 
effective in providing flexibility in meeting and preserving incentives for policy changes, and in 
maintaining  ongoing  engagement,  with  a  longer-term  outlook  than  the  usual  two-tranche

4.  Justification for the Sixth Poverty Reduction Support Credit  
 
37.  PRSC 6 addresses three key areas of macro policy and institutional reforms for (i) 
supporting  the  transition  to  a  market  economy  by  removing  structural  weaknesses  and 
improving  the  business  environment,  (ii)  making  development  socially  inclusive  and 
environmentally friendly, and (iii) modernizing governance and the public administration system. 
The policy actions identified in the PRSC 6 policy matrix are built on the reform measures 
achieved  under  previous  PRSCs.  The  preparation  of  PRSC  6  was  built  on  the  strong 
commitment by the ODA community to (i) support Viet Nam’s reform agenda through nationwide 
implementation  of  the  SEDP,  and  (ii)  galvanize  interest  for  the  reform  program  among 
stakeholders.  Development  partners  have  increasingly  united  around  the  PRSC  as  an 
instrument for policy dialogue. They have been actively involved in supporting implementation of 
the reform agenda, analytical work, technical assistance, project lending, and program lending 
or grant support. The rationale for providing financial support under PRSC 6 comes from the 
external financing needed to cover the cost of reform adjustments. The policy actions supported 
by  the  PRSC  process—including  recapitalization  of  SOCBs,  operation  of  a  safety  net  for 
workers  who  become  redundant  as  a  result  of  SOE  restructuring,  expansion  of  budget 
appropriations for the education sector, and creation of provincial health care funds for the 
poor—entail a substantial additional cost to the Government.  
 
38.  Justification  for  PRSC  6  is  grounded  on  three  criteria:  (i)  prudent  macroeconomic 
management to ensure that progress on the long-term reform agenda will not be undermined by 
short-term instability; (ii) the Government’s own assessment of progress accomplished in SEDP 
implementation; and (iii) the strategic reform actions for PRSC 6, which were identified based on 
analytical input, and have been complied with.  
 
39.  IMF’s  assessment  of  Viet  Nam’s  economic  performance  confirms  the  country’s 
impressive overall record of economic performance in 2006 and broadly favorable prospects for 
2007 (Appendix 3). Based on the joint assessment by the World Bank and IMF, the SEDP is 
fiscally sustainable, despite the high level of investment associated with the development of 
large-scale  infrastructure.  The  baseline  scenario  of  the  most  recent  debt  sustainability 
assessment (DSA) is broadly in line with the investment and growth outlook of the SEDP. The 
DSA estimates that public and publicly-guaranteed debt will increase from nearly 44% of GDP in 
2005 to about 51% by 2011. This increase is still considered manageable, as more than half will 
remain on highly concessional terms. In addition, external debt (both public and private) is 
projected to decline from over 32% to under 31% of GDP. Viet Nam should thus remain at low 
risk of external debt distress.14

A.  Impact and Outcome 
46.  The program loan aims to provide support to Viet Nam’s policy and institutional reforms 
that  seek  to  maintain  high  growth  and  reduce  poverty.  The  outcomes  envisaged  include 
numerous development targets that reduce structural weaknesses, promote socially inclusive 
development, protect natural resources, and modernize governance and public administration 
(Appendix  1) by  supporting  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  program under  the policy 
framework of PRSC 6. To reduce poverty and sustain rapid economic growth, the program loan 
will strengthen Viet Nam’s reform program through 40 policy actions, 12 of which are tranche 
release  conditions  for  the  loan.  The  policy  matrix  is  presented  in  Appendix  4  and  the 
development  policy  letter  in  Appendix  7.  Supplementary  Appendix  B  provides  additional 
information on supporting documents demonstrating that all of the policy actions have already 
been complied with. The program’s Summary Poverty Impact Assessment elaborates the effect 
of this program loan to the poor, and is presented in Appendix 8. The policy matrix comprises 
policy measures that can be categorized into four reform pillars: 
 
(i)  Pillar  I:  business  development.  Promote  global  integration  to  improve  the 
economy’s  efficiency  and  resource  allocation,  enhance  transparency  and 
accountability  in  state  and  financial  sectors,  and  strengthen  the  regulatory 
framework  for  private  sector  and  infrastructure  development  to  create  an 
enabling business environment and improved livelihoods for the poor.  
(ii)  Pillar  II:  social  inclusion.  Advance  human  development  by  upgrading  the 
quality of education, promoting inclusive education for disadvantaged children,

14 
improving access by the poor to health services, helping secure social protection 
for the population, and promoting gender equality.   
(iii)  Pillar III: natural resources. Encourage important policy measures leading to 
more sustainable management of natural resources, including the protection of 
land, forests, water and the environment.  
(iv)  Pillar IV: modern governance. Increase transparency and accountability of the  
planning  process,  public  financial  management,  and  public  administration, 
improve legal transparency and accessibility as part of a broader effort to build 
modern governance; and fight corruption.  
 
The possible approaches to mitigate potential risks in attaining the program’s outcomes include 
(i)  upgrading  of  policies  related  to  the  banking  sector,  the  securities  market  and  the 
management of public debt; (ii) improving data availability and analytical work on issues arising 
from rural-urban disparities; and (iii) making rapid improvements in transparency at various 
levels. The potential risks and their mitigating measures will be discussed in detail in Section V 
(Program Benefits, Impacts, Assumptions, and Risks).  
 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
47.  The program loan’s outputs include (i) policy advisory services by all PRSC participants 
to  assist  the  Government  in  formulating  and  implementing  the  reform  policies;  (ii)  laws, 
regulations, and policies that are conducive to reforms under the program framework; (iii) 
amendment or strengthening of laws, regulations, and policies; (iv) action plans and strategies 
that  are  strategically  important  for  attaining  targeted  development  outcomes;  and  (v)  self-
assessments and sector studies that are of strategic importance. These were achieved through 
40 policy actions in the program’s policy matrix. The following paragraphs will elaborate in detail 
certain outputs achieved under the reform program through the strategic and critical policy 
actions under the program framework.  
 
  1.  Pillar I: Business Development  
   
48.  Global Integration. The most important PRSC 6 policy actions in relation to global 
integration were the granting of trading and distribution rights to all foreign firms, in line with 
international  commitments,  and  the  issuance  of  regulations  and  adequate  enforcement 
mechanisms to guide the intellectual property law. The trend in the area of global integration 
has shifted from reducing barriers to trade in goods towards increased competition in services 
and considerable legal reform. This trend was boosted (on a multilateral as opposed to bilateral 
basis) through Viet Nam’s WTO accession in January 2007.  
49.  SOE Reform. Significant progress in SOE reform occurred between mid-2006 and mid-
2007, in the form of additional divestiture and better performance monitoring. The number of 
sectors in which 100% state ownership is to be retained was further reduced (from 29 to 19), 
and the remaining activities are primarily strategic in nature. This should lead to more SOEs 
being divested, with share auctions now utilized as the main mechanism for equitization, and 
the participation of foreign strategic investors allowed. Although the state still retains a share of 
the capital in many sectors and enterprises, additional steps have been taken to ensure that 
these are managed efficiently. All SOEs are now classified according to their performance— 
based on their turnover, profitability, servicing of debts and compliance with the law—with the 
classification results published. In addition, the exercise of ownership rights on behalf of the 
state is being transferred from line ministries and provincial governments to the State Capital 
Investment Corporation (SCIC), a for-profit organization under the Prime Minister. This transfer

15 
of ownership should resolve the conflict of interest that ministries and provinces formerly faced 
when formulating and implementing policies that affected the enterprises they ran. This also 
enables  a  shift  away  from  administrative  management  towards  commercially  oriented 
management of SOEs. Corporate governance at the equitized SOEs is also expected to be 
improved. The former holdings of line ministries and agencies in nearly 200 equitized SOEs 
were  transferred  to  SCIC.  This  has  resulted  in  improved  corporate  governance,  as  SCIC 
operation is more commercially oriented. By 2006, the number of equitized SOEs totaled 3,060. 
There were over 2,100 remaining SOEs, including 335 public utility companies and 295 public 
farms. The Government plans to equitize 1,500 additional SOEs by end-2010. The Government 
also accelerated the equitization of over 71 general corporations, with 20 scheduled to be 
equitized  in  2007.  A  number  of  large  general  corporations—including  four  state-owned 
commercial banks, telecommunication companies such as Viet Nam Mobile Telecom Services 
Company (MobiFone), VinaPhone Telecoms Operator Service Company (VinaFone), and Hanoi 
and Saigon Brewery Companies—are preparing their initial public offerings (IPOs). Overall, 
equitization helps improve the performance of enterprises. A survey of 550 equitized SOEs in 
2005 showed that 90 percent of the companies reported improved financial performance, with 
increases in sales of 13% and profit increases of nearly 10%. Salaries of employees in those 
companies also increased.18  
 
50.  The Government has requested ADB to provide assistance in (i) accelerating the pace of 
SOE  reform,  including  equitization  and  listing  on  the  stock  exchange;  and  (ii)  promoting 
development of a market-based and internationally competitive corporate sector by providing 
long-term finance. A preparatory TA project and two subsequent program loans on SOE reform 
(SOE Reform and Corporate Governance Facilities I and II) are included in Viet Nam CSP 
2007–2010.  
51.  Financial Sector Reform. An important policy action under the previous program loan 
was adoption of the ambitious banking reform strategy, which established a deadline of 2010 for 
equitization  of  state-owned  commercial  banks.  This  program  loan  now  focuses  on  the 
implementation of a strategy aiming to strengthen the commercial orientation of SOCBs, which 
still dominate the market, based on the assumption that regulation and technical upgrades alone 
would not be sufficient to overcome the interference of non-commercial objectives in lending 
decisions, especially at the provincial level. Introducing private capital in SOCBs, with the 
participation of strategic foreign investors with recognized resources and expertise, was seen as 
necessary to accomplish this transformation. The program loan’s policy actions under PRSC 6 
prepared the ground for the equitization of two SOCBs, including one of the largest, over the 
next year. The equity stake allowed to foreign strategic investors was increased, while all 
SOCBs were required to disclose their financial statements in line with internationally accepted 
standards.  
52.  Private  Sector  Development.  Policies  to  support  the  development  of  the  already 
vibrant private sector remain centered around the removal of administrative barriers to entry. 
Through this program loan, processing time was reduced and the fee structure for business 
registration was rationalized. The authority to issue investment certificates was clarified, more 
details were provided on sectors where investment is conditional, and the documentation for 
investment registration or evaluation was standardized. A consultative mechanism to streamline 
licenses  and  oversee  the  implementation  of  a  new  investment-enterprise  regime  was 
established, and guidelines and options were issued for foreign investors to transition to such   a

covers registration, tax, and seal formalities. A monitoring mechanism to assess the constraints 
faced by businesses was set up in parallel, under the form of an investment climate module

53.  Infrastructure.  Mechanisms  are  being  set  up  to  increase  the  efficiency  of  public

the road transport sector. About 40 projects will be transferred to the Viet Nam Roads Authority, 
which previously was responsible only for the maintenance budget. The transfer of investment

its former dual role as project owner and supervisor. The adoption of wastewater charges based 
on  cost  recovery  should  also  contribute  to  the  sustainability  of  investments  in  water  and 
sanitation.  This  measure  is  accompanied  by  appropriate  caps  to  protect  the  poor.  The 
mobilization of private funding for infrastructure projects should be facilitated by the newly 
issued  build-operate-transfer  decree,  which  clarifies  contract  specifications,  investor 
qualifications and treatment of unsolicited proposals. 
 
2.  Pillar II: Social Inclusion  
 
54.  Education. The government strategy expanded coverage of high-quality schooling at 
lower levels with competition and incentives for excellence at higher levels. While the coverage 
of primary education has continued to expand, quality remains an issue, with children in poorer 
areas being at a disadvantage. Fundamental quality standard levels for schools were introduced 
under the previous PRSC cycle, and a key policy action under this program loan extends 
performance standards for primary teachers nationwide. The implementation of such standards 
will rely on evidence-based assessments of teacher performance, as opposed to diplomas and 
seniority. In addition, transparent criteria for university admission quotas have been adopted on 
a pilot basis. 
55.  Health. A fundamental transformation in the government’s approach to HIV/AIDS has 
taken place in recent years and is now being consolidated. Risky behaviors—including the 
practice of commercial sex and the use of intravenous drugs—were traditionally labeled as 
“social evils”, often resulting in stigma and discrimination for the affected populations. That 
approach changed considerably under the previous cycle, with a new strategy emphasizing 
prevention  and  treatment  over  repression.  This  public  health  approach  is  reflected  in  the 
HIV/AIDS law passed in June 2006 and the subsequent preparation of a comprehensive set of 
action plans to expand harm reduction. These action plans foresee the introduction of needle 
exchange and methadone substitution programs. Meanwhile, an effort was undertaken across 
the health sector as a whole to improve the budgetary balance between health infrastructure, 
human resources, subsidies and preventive care.  
56.  Social Protection. The pension program design was improved, extending coverage and 
make  its  compulsory  component  financially  viable.  Until  the  mid-1990s,  only  public  sector 
workers were entitled to old-age, disability and survivor benefits, under a non-contributory 
program  funded  out  of  general  government  resources.  This  program  was  subsequently 
extended on a contributory basis to all formal sector workers, but old-age pension benefits 
remained determined by average salaries in the years preceding retirement. The period covered 
by this credit saw the passing of the first-ever Social Insurance Law, which determines pension

17 
benefits for private sector workers on the basis of their average salary over all the years in 
which they contributed. In a rapidly growing economy, this average salary is substantially lower 
than the salary in the years preceding retirement, so the law dramatically improved the financial 
viability of the system. It also introduced a voluntary pension program for farmers and informal 
sector workers, making it possible to gradually extend the coverage of the social insurance 
system. This voluntary program is currently in its design phase. However, current pension 
formulas retain shortcomings despite the system’s stronger financial viability and its potentially 
broader  coverage.  Under  the  new  law,  there  are  considerable  gaps  between  the  level  of 
benefits for men and women, and for public and private sector workers. In addition, benefits are 
far  removed  from  the  actuarial  benchmark,  which  encourages  relatively  short  contribution 
periods and underreporting of earnings.   
57.  Gender. While gender equality indicators are better in Viet Nam than in many other 
developing countries, steps are being taken to narrow the remaining gaps. The passing of a law 
on gender equality, a policy action taken under this program loan, is an important step in this 
direction. It is recognized that regulation alone is not sufficient, as abuses are often unreported 
and enforcement capacities limited, but the new law does serve to unify the legal framework to 
address gender disparities and increases women’s participation in decision making. 
3.  Pillar III: Natural Resources  
 
58.  Land  and  Forest.  Two  main  issues  stand  out  in  relation  to  land.  First,  forest 
management remains largely under the control of state forestry enterprises (SFEs), which has 
resulted in a mixing of commercial and protective functions. There is a risk, however, that SFE 
restructuring could lead to encroachment upon forest land by outsiders, to the detriment of local 
populations, especially ethnic minorities, whose livelihoods depend to a large extent on the use 
of forests as a public good. To address this risk, the government issued the National Forest 
Development Strategy, which is designed to strengthen linkages between the protective and 
economic functions of forests, and to promote ownership by local households and communities. 
The strategy addresses revisions to the 5 million hectare Forest Plan, and aims to improve the 
balance between forest protection and multi-purpose forestation, and promotes policies that 
encourage farmers to live with the forests.  
59.  The second critical issue faced by Viet Nam in relation to land management concerns 
land conversion, reclamation and resettlement in the context of rapid urbanization. Close to one 
million people may be moving every year to urban and peri-urban areas, and there is extensive 
clearing of land for infrastructure development or to host industrial parks. Lack of transparency 
in reclamation and conversion plans may result in sizeable capital gains for those with access to 
the relevant information, while insufficient compensation for affected populations is leading to 
recurrent social unrest. The Land Law, approved under the previous PRSC series, paved the 
way for the use of market prices as the basis for compensation. But gaps remained in relation to 
land occupants lacking appropriate tenure documentation, which is common, as the transfer of 
land to households and firms is still ongoing in Viet Nam. Under PRSC 6, resettlement and 
compensation procedures have been clarified for those cases where occupants lack a land use 
right certificate (LUC), and mechanisms have been set up to handle complaints. 
60.  Environment. Development sustainability also depends on the appropriate control of 
pollution and environmental damage resulting from both public and private sector business 
activities.  Considerable  progress  was  made  during  the  previous  cycle  on  the  use  of 
environmental  impact  assessments  for  large  investment  projects.  This  program  loan  now 
requires both mandatory consultation with communities where projects are to be located and 
incorporation of local feedback when reporting back to the relevant authorities.

4.  Pillar IV: Modern Governance 
 
61.  Planning Process. The transformation of planning processes—from the direct allocation 
of resources to the strategic steering of the economy—has continued during the current 5-year 
period of the SEDP 2006-2010. In the command and control economy, the MPI would play the 
role of an arbiter in the selection of investment projects submitted by various government 
bodies. With investment decisions devolved to the National Assembly and People’s Councils, 
the role of MPI has shifted towards the allocation of the budget envelope available for capital 
expenditures. Norms were adopted to allocate state capital expenditures transparently across 
provinces,  using  criteria  such  as  population,  poverty  and  ethnicity,  and  served  to  make 
considerably  more  resources  available  to  poorer  provinces.  In  addition,  regulations  were 
adopted for the preparation of regional development plans, specifying responsibilities, requiring 
disclosure,  and  requiring  that  infrastructure  master  plans  be  based  on  broader  regional 
development  plans.  As  a  result,  issues  such  as  comparative  advantage,  land  use  and 
population flows are expected to gain importance in determining infrastructure network layouts. 
62.  Public Financial Management. Public financial management reform has focused on 
strengthening systems and increasing transparency. The State Audit of Viet Nam (SAV) was 
established as a specialized agency under the National Assembly towards the end of the 
previous cycle, resulting in the first-ever disclosure of the SAV audit results and annual audit 
plan. In addition, a report on budget execution for the current year and the budget plan for 
forthcoming  year  were  both  published;  these  will  be  published  annually  in  the  future. 
Regulations were also issued requiring periodic disclosure of the amount and composition of 
external public debt, signaling an increased emphasis on the management of resources and 
liabilities, as compared to the previous focus on public expenditures. In addition, a regulation to 
guide the establishment and issuance of benchmark government bonds was implemented, and 
the administrative procedures for all taxes were consolidated into a single law, modernizing 
assessment and enforcement methods. 
63.  Legal Development. Increased oversight of government actions at both national and 
local levels has been a common theme underlying the legal reforms adopted under this program 
loan. The National Assembly has become increasingly active in its supervisory role, especially 
since the passing of the Budget Law of 2002. This trend was reinforced recently with the 
establishment of separate legal, judicial, economic, and budget committees, which are expected 
to include a greater proportion of permanent members than in the past. A key new task of the 
judiciary committee will be overseeing the Government’s anticorruption activities. A separate 
legislative committee will be in a better position to ensure consistency between different laws, 
improve the quality of their drafting, and coordinate the assessments and recommendations of 
the various National Assembly committees on proposed legislation. A similar trend is noticeable 
at local levels. A new ordinance on grassroots democracy strengthens information disclosure, 
public participation, and accountability of officials in the preparation and implementation of 
commune-level policies. Recent legal developments have also aimed at promoting access to 
justice and recognizing civil society organizations. Under this operation, legal aid mechanisms 
for marginalized and vulnerable groups were simplified and broadened, and policies adopted 
encouraging the participation of non-state establishments in the delivery of public services. 
64.  Fighting Corruption. The Government is now moving to implement its anticorruption 
program. Key laws and regulations have been passed, including the pivotal Anticorruption Law. 
The  current  challenge—of  translating  resolve  into  action—has  been  addressed  in  part  by 
several measures adopted during the period covered by this credit. These include establishment 
of a steering committee against corruption, headed by the Prime Minister, which has the power

19 
to suspend high-level officials if they are suspected of wrongdoing. It is already engaged in 
investigating some high-profile cases, and the findings are to be made public. In addition, the 
office  of  the  national  steering  committee  was  set  up  under  the  Anticorruption  Law  as  an 
independent entity, which does not belong to the existing government agency system. The 
results of corruption investigations in cases overseen by the Government Inspectorate were 
disclosed, and a legal framework established to protect and reward corruption-related whistle-
blowing.  
C.  Important Features 
65.  An environmental assessment has been prepared for the policy matrix of the program 
loan in keeping with the ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and the environmental safeguard 
requirements of ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines.19  
 
66.  On balance, the reforms proposed as part of this program loan are expected to have 
wide-reaching positive impacts on socioeconomic conditions  throughout Viet Nam and  will 
assist the Government fulfill its development objectives as outlined in the SEDP. The majority of 
the proposed reforms are likely to have either a positive impact or no impact. Where possible, 
enhancement  measures  have  been  developed  for  integration  into  the  reform  process  to 
optimize the predicted positive impacts. Two series of reforms—those relating to (i) an increase 
in granting of trading and distribution rights to foreign firms, and (ii) to increased private sector 
development—have been identified as having an unknown impact, because of their potential to 
result in both positive and negative effects. Mitigation measures have been developed to offset 
any potential adverse impacts and maximize their positive impacts. No reforms have been 
identified as having a negative impact. 
 
67.  Monitoring relating to environmental issues will be integrated into the overall monitoring 
program developed for PRSC operations; a series of suggested environment-related monitoring 
indicators has been developed for this purpose.  
 
68.  The program loan will not have any impact on involuntary resettlement or on indigenous 
people, as it has no investment component. None of the policy actions associated with this 
program will trigger any activities related to indigenous people during the implementation period. 
The current PRSC cycle recognizes the potential risk of income disparity between urban and 
rural as well as the Kinh majority and ethnic minorities, as did PRSC 5. The Government is 
aware of this potential risk and commits to formulating and implementing preventative and 
mitigating measures. This potential risk is not viewed as being likely to damage Viet Nam’s track 
record on these issues during the short program implementation period. A social and poverty 
impact assessment was undertaken in relation to the program loan (see Appendix 8). The 
assessment concludes that the activities will have no adverse impacts on indigenous people, 
and no gender implications.

published  in  2005,  provided  an  update  and  review  of  the  implementation  of  the 
recommendations  of  the  2001-CFAA  and  also  suggested  reforms  in  other  areas.  The 
government has made steady progress in implementing the 2004 PER-IFA recommendations. 
Major developments in public financial management include empowering the National Assembly 
with  increased  government  accountability  for  the  use  of  public  resources;  increasing 
transparency  for  all  agencies  using  budget  resources,  including  SOEs,  public  investment 
projects and statutory funds; establishing the SAV as a technically independent unit under the 
National  Assembly;  and  gradual  integration  of  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures  through 
forward-looking  budgets  and  resource  allocation  norms.  Twenty-six  national  private  sector 
accounting and 37 auditing standards consistent with international practice have been issued. 
The government is currently making a major investment in a new and integrated Treasury and 
Budget Management Information System (TABMIS). Progress is being made in developing new 
business processes for TABMIS, including (i) a unified Chart of Accounts, (ii) further integration 
of  recurrent  and  capital  budget  execution  processes,  (iii)  clarification  of  issues  related  to 
reporting ODA  on budget, and (iv) development  of  standard reports  to  strengthen budget 
execution. 
 
79.  The World Bank and MOF commenced preparation of the CFAA Update in April 2007 in 
consultation with and with the participation of many other development partners, including 
ADB,23 AusAID, Canada, Denmark, DFID, EC, France, Germany, Ireland, and Sweden. The 
final report will be available in late 2007. The update will provide an assessment of public 
financial management by examining budget development, budget execution and accounting, 
internal and external reporting, internal controls, internal and external auditing, monitoring and 
legislative oversight and scrutiny, financial management capacity and financial accountability 
risks.  
 
80.  The fiduciary risks of the current public financial management systems, (budgeting, 
accounting, reporting and auditing) are assessed as moderate. Since the IMF does not currently 
have  a  program  in  Viet  Nam,  it  is  not  possible  to  rely  on  its  assessment  of  the  control 
environment of the SBV. However, the enactment of the Audit Law of 2005 helps address the 
issues related to audit and accounting arrangements. The Audit Law has established the SAV 
as an independent institution reporting to the National Assembly, with the auditor general being 
appointed and dismissed by the National Assembly. Audit reports were made public for the first 
time in 2006. The SBV will be subject to auditing by SAV on an annual basis.

expenditure tracking survey, as well as quarterly progress reports from the relevant sector

implementation  requirements,  the  monitoring  of  progress  towards  development  outcomes 
cannot be conducted on an annual basis. It is expected that the new PRSC cycle will involve 
some annual monitoring but only two in-depth assessments, towards the middle and at the end 
of the cycle. 
 
V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
84.  First, through policy actions designed to facilitate business development, the loan will 
increase efficiency, accelerate economic growth, and create jobs. These policy actions will help 
improve the regulatory framework for private sector development, and enhance transparency 
and accountability in SOE operations and in banking. Second, policy actions addressing social 
inclusion will result in benefits that include improved quality of education, improved access of 
the poor to health services, a reformed social protection system, and promotion of gender 
equality. Third, through policy actions addressing natural resources, the loan will help secure 
land ownership and address the resettlement and compensation process, as well as promoting 
more sustainable management of natural resources. Fourth, through policy actions addressing 
modern  governance,  benefits  include  increased  transparency  and  accountability  of  public 
finances, and improved legal transparency and accessibility. These will be achieved through 
better coordination of plans and budgets, adoption of the medium-term expenditure framework, 
and greater accountability in public finance and public administration. 
   
85.  Three  potential  risks  are  associated  with  emerging  imbalances  accompanying  Viet 
Nam’s entry into a new phase of development, with greater global integration and a more 
market-oriented economy. The first potential risk is the vulnerability that stems from possible 
turbulence in the financial sector, as the supervisory and regulatory capacity of  monetary 
authorities has not matched the expansion in capital markets. The second risk relates to the 
massive inflows of FDI and increased competition in formerly protected sectors. This change

24 
may test the ability of Viet Nam to preserve social inclusion, and may cause some groups to 
lose in the short term. The third possible risk involves potential corruption and social strife 
related to rapid urbanization and infrastructure development. 
 
86.  Through  appropriate  measures  and  proactive  programs  undertaken  during  program 
implementation, the Government will take steps to mitigate potential risks. ADB, along with other 
PRSC financing partners, has conducted analytical studies to help policymakers formulate and 
execute  mitigating  and  corrective  measures  in  anticipation  of  these  potential  risks.  These 
corrective measures have been included in the proposed series of PRSCs, which includes this 
program loan. The first risk—related to imbalance in the financial sector—could be addressed 
by rapid upgrading of policies related to the banking sector, the securities market and the 
management of public debt, all of which are part of the proposed reform program. The second 
risk—related to social inclusion and environmental sustainability—could be mitigated by the 
strong commitment of the Government to keep growth inclusive and sustainable. This risk could 
also be addressed through improvements in data availability and analytical work on issues 
arising from rural-urban disparities, which are included as part of the PRSC process. Rapid 
feedback channels from affected stakeholders, inclusive policies in the social sectors, and 
transparent mechanisms to transfer resources to poorer regions are among the mitigating 
measures supported by the proposed series of operations. The third risk—related to corruption 
and  social  strife  caused  by  rapid  urbanization  and  infrastructure  development—could  be 
addressed by making rapid progress in transparency at various levels, including in regional 
planning, infrastructure master plans, land use and appropriate taxation, and monitoring of the 
assets of relevant civil servants.

1.  Formulation of the Plan 
 
1.  Comprehensive  economic  reforms  undertaken  during  the  last  Poverty  Reduction 
Support Credit (PRSC) cycle have led to rapid economic growth and remarkable progress on 
development outcomes. Viet Nam has been among the fastest-growing economies in the world 
for  almost  two  decades.  There  was  a  considerable  acceleration  of  reforms  around  2001, 
justifying the first 5-year PRSC cycle, and then again in 2006. The former involved (i) the 
passing of an enterprise law that greatly facilitated business registration and operation, (ii) the 
signing of a bilateral trade agreement with the United States that strengthened global integration 
and resulted in important legal improvements, and (iii) the adoption of the first serious steps 
towards  state-owned enterprise (SOE) divestiture and the strengthening of public financial 
management. Emerging from massive poverty less than two decades ago, Viet Nam is now 
aiming to attain middle-income status by 2010.  
 
2.  The new socioeconomic development plan (SEDP) 2006–2010 articulates the aim to 
attain middle-income status by 2010, reflecting the transition towards strategic planning for a 
market economy. The SEDP, approved by the National Assembly in June 2006, illustrates the 
depth of Viet Nam’s transition. Unlike previous 5-year plans, which focused on quantitative 
targets as if the state was still in charge of producing most goods and services, the SEDP 
emphasizes development outcomes and the policy reforms needed to attain them. It relies on 
data  analysis  rather  than  administrative  reporting  to  substantiate  its  diagnosis  and 
recommendations. It has also led to the adoption of a framework to monitor progress towards 
attaining development outcomes.  
 
3.  The official development assistance (ODA) community has aligned its efforts behind the 
SEDP, while acknowledging that other key documents will shape reforms in the coming years. 
Such  alignment  is  a  testament  to  the  strong  ownership  of  the  reform  program  by  the 
Government of Viet Nam (the Government). It also reflects satisfaction with the process through 
which  the  SEDP  was  prepared.  Above  all,  the  SEDP  is  seen  as  both  a  credible  and  a 
sustainable strategy to foster economic growth and poverty reduction. It is credible because of 
the ambitious policy reforms it proposes, which are organized around three pillars: (i) supporting 
business development, (ii) keeping growth inclusive, and (iii) better managing natural resources. 
A fourth, underlying pillar concerns the need to modernize institutions so as to deliver on the 
other three fronts. The SEDP is seen as sustainable because it should lead to manageable 
levels of public debt by 2010. 
 
4.  Unlike the previous SEDP, the new SEDP is focused and clearly defines development 
targets, identifies appropriate policies to attain those targets, and aligns resources to those 
policies.  The  country’s  development  goals,  which  are  a  local  version  of  the  Millennium 
Development Goals, are among the key targets pursued in the SEDP (Table A2.1); this parallels 
how key targets were pursued in the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy 
(CPRGS) that governed the previous PRSC cycle.  
 
5.  The SEDP provides a framework for poverty reduction policies, programs, and actions in 
Viet  Nam  (Figure  A2.1).  The  ODA  community  has  adopted  the  SEDP  as  the  reference 
document for planning and formulating external assistance.
